text: Easter Sunday 2010
a massive earthquake devastates towns
and cities in Baja California Mexico
this was the largest earthquake in last
20 years in this region it caused
extensive damage locally and was felled
as far as San Diego 100 miles
to find the fault geologists turned to
the sky
what they find is completely unexpected
none of the known fault lines have
ruptured we thought it was another
famous Fault in that region whose
religion is a lot of fault but the
actual location of the earthquake was 60
miles away the contrasting colors of the
satellite image trace a previously
unknown Fault in the KU Kapaa mountains
it's a surprise because we know okay we
saw something new but the scale of the
quake doesn't make sense the new fault
line is just 30 miles long it's too
small to be responsible for all the
damage it turns out that looking at the
surface of the earth to understand what
happens deep is a very tricky problem to
solve the puzzle geologists switched to
an advanced satellite technology called
InSAR so USERRA means interferometric a
synthetic aperture radar so it's a radar
in SAR measures how the height of the
ground has changed creating colored
patterns called fringes
it's like contours on a map when they're
really close together that means the
fault is gonna be nearby
the results of the radar analysis are a
shock the colored fringes trace the
position of a hidden fault line running
all the way from Baja to the Gulf of
California half of the rupture wasn't
visible it was actually a lot larger
erupted lengths of over 75 miles
this massive fault line which started in
the cou Kapaa mountains and then
extended much farther south unleashed
the equivalent energy of 40 atomic bombs
on the region
but how could scientists have not
spotted the full length of the fault you
can't map what you can't see
so what concealed the fault line the
answer lies in the vast Colorado mud
flats where the fault lies this fault
rupture occurred beneath a big pile of
fine-grained wet sediment along a large
area of the Colorado River Delta
the intense shaking from the powerful
quake caused the soil to act like a
liquid filling up cracks in the ground
once there shaking a stop then
everything kind of settles down into a
new place and it looks like solid ground
again
